The Victorian era, spanning the reign of Queen Victoria from 1837 to 1901, was a time of significant change in English literature. This period saw the rise of the novel as a popular form of literature, with authors like Charles Dickens and Thomas Hardy gaining widespread acclaim. The literature of this era often reflected the social issues of the time, such as the effects of industrialization and the widening gap between the rich and the poor. What was a common theme in Victorian era literature?
A. The glorification of the monarchy
B. The exploration of fantasy worlds
C. The reflection of social issues of the time
D. The celebration of rural life

A common theme in Victorian era literature was C. The reflection of social issues of the time. This period was marked by rapid industrialization, urbanization, and social change, which authors often explored in their works. For example, Charles Dickens' novels often depicted the harsh realities of life for the poor and the working class, while Thomas Hardy's works delved into the contrast between rural traditions and modern industrial society. These authors, among others, used literature as a means to comment on and critique the social inequalities and moral dilemmas of their time.
